title: 115_hr5766
content: The Act may be cited as the "Securing Public Areas of Transportation Facilities Act of 2018". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act defines "public and private sector stakeholders" and "surface transportation asset" as facilities, equipment, or systems used for transportation services by public transportation agencies, railroad carriers, and entities offering scheduled services. The Act defines "public and private sector stakeholders" and "surface transportation asset" as facilities, equipment, or systems used for transportation services by public transportation agencies, railroad carriers, and entities offering scheduled services, including over-the-road bus transportation services, bus terminals, and other transportation facilities determined by the Secretary. SEC. 3. PUBLIC AREA SECURITY WORKING GROUP. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a working group to enhance security in public areas of transportation facilities by promoting collaboration, information sharing, coordinated incident response procedures, and prevention of terrorist attacks through various security measures. The Secretary of Homeland Security will report annually on the working group's activities, findings, and recommendations for enhancing security in transportation facilities through infrastructure protection and advanced security technologies. The working group established under subsection (a) will provide informative reports to the public in accordance with section 552(b) of title 5, United States Code. The Federal Advisory Committee Act (5 U.S.C. App.) does not apply to this working group or any subsidiary. SEC. 4. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE. The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to inform and provide technical assistance to owners and operators of surface transportation assets to enhance resilience. Best practices for protecting public areas of transportation facilities must be published within a year. Best practices for protecting public areas of transportation facilities, including surface transportation assets, must be updated periodically. The Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration must review regulations on transporting firearms and ammunition within a year of this Act. A report will be submitted to relevant committees with potential modifications. Collaboration with the Aviation Security Advisory Committee and stakeholders is required for this review. The House of Representatives passed the Act on June 25, 2018. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
